abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Critical Imports
            Project (CIP) for Albania was fully satisfactory. Both Bank
            and Borrower performance are considered highly satisfactory
            as well. The CIP's experience and lessons are generally
            consistent with those of other recent emergency import
            components in transition countries. Findings and lessons
            learned are: (a) A positive-list emergency import project
            can be an effective tool for addressing urgent production
            bottlenecks while simultaneously supporting a reform
            process, provided that there is built-in project flexibility
            and substantial Government commitment and proactive Bank
            supervision to respond quickly to the changing needs. (b)
            Timeliness is paramount. The Bank's responsiveness to
            Albania's needs in 1992 and 1993 won it considerable
            credibility with the Government and resulted in a close and
            productive Government-Bank relationship over those years. To
            some extent, there are tradeoffs between timeliness and
            urgency on the one hand and thorough preparation and
            meticulous implementation on the other. (c) Considering that
            Albania was going through a difficult transition and that
            income and demand were limited, the project's design
            should have taken into consideration that imports to the
            private sector may not sell rapidly at full CIF landed
            prices. Auctions might have been a more appropriate way to
            distribute goods quickly, while simultaneously building a
            private suppliers network. (d) Emergency import projects
            like all other projects require the establishment of
            accounting and management information systems (MIS). A MIS
            system for the CIP would have resulted in better tracking of
            local project costs and of the distribution of goods to end
            users. (e) Unplanned but important project benefits included
            (1) knowledge and skills transfer (especially procurement);
            and (2) development of sectoral dialogues, leading to a
            strengthening of the subsequent loan portfolio. (f) An
            import project in a new borrower country requires early
            attention to procurement, including hands-on training and
            support by Bank procurement staff and the appointment of
            project procurement advisers. This early emphasis on
            economic and efficient procurement discipline can set the
            stage for the development of a transparent procurement
            environment in the country. (g) Higher than average
            resources are needed when working with new borrowers,
            especially in transition countries. Bank effort is required
            to assist the Government with specific implementation
            issues, as well as to redesign project components in the
            face of emerging realities. The CIP was not only processed
            and approved on a fast-track basis, but continued to be
            closely supervised during implementation, which was a factor
            in its success.

18156898.trustfund: TF031197-ALBANIA - CRITICAL IMPORTS,TF022695-CRITICAL IMPORTS PROJECT,TF031198-ALBANIA - CRITICAL IMPORTS PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Critical Imports Project's
            objective is to help maintain and increase capacity
            utilization and production in key productive sectors during
            the next 12 to 18 months. The project will provide critical
            goods and materials to enable vital sectors of the economy
            to continue to operate. It will finance the priority import
            requirements of the agriculture and power sectors. The
            agriculture component provides urgent inputs for crop and
            poultry/egg production in 1992/93; spare parts for
            agricultural mechanization and irrigation. The power
            component will provide materials and equipment for: repairs
            of generating plants; rehabilitation of the transmission
            system; improvements in the dispatching/monitoring system;
            and rehabilitation of the distribution network in Tirana,
            Shkoder, and Durres. The transport component includes spare
            parts, batteries and tires for trucks; spare parts for the
            port at Durres, and telecommunications systems for the
            railways. Finally, under the general administration
            component, the project will finance imports of office
            equipment for the public entities involved in project implementation.
